metadata.case_name: Bipul alias Mohan Chaudhri v. Chief Commissioner, Tripura

facts.text: On October 26, 1962, the President issued a Proclamation declaring Emergency under Art. 352 due to Chinese aggression.
Proclamation laid before Parliament on November 8, 1962, approved by Rajya Sabha on November 13, 1962, and Lok Sabha on November 14, 1962.
President promulgated Defence of India Ordinance IV of 1962 on October 26, 1962, empowering Central Government to make rules under s.3.
Defence of India Rules, 1962 promulgated on November 5, 1962; r.30 empowers detention if necessary to prevent prejudicial acts.
President's Order dated November 3, 1962 under Art.359(1) suspending right to move any court for enforcement of Arts.21 and 22 if deprived under Defence of India Ordinance or rules/orders thereunder.
Chief Commissioner of Tripura issued detention order against petitioner Bipul alias Mohan Chaudhri on November 20, 1962 under r.30, directing detention in Agartala Central Jail.
Petitioner filed Habeas Corpus petition under Art.32 dated November 30, 1962 from Agartala Central Jail.
Petition forwarded to Supreme Court by Tripura Administration but initially withheld as not maintainable.
Chief Commissioner ordered transfer of petitioner to Hazaribagh Central Jail on December 3, 1962 under r.30(5).
Petitioner filed contempt petition from Hazaribagh dated December 15/18, 1962 alleging withholding of Art.32 petition.
Supreme Court on January 28, 1963 issued notice on contempt petition.
Shri S.C. Mazumdar filed affidavit apologizing unconditionally for withholding petition; produced original petition.
Division Bench on February 18, 1963 accepted apology and directed posting of Habeas Corpus petition.
Constitution Bench on March 27, 1963 issued Rule, hearing within 10 days; petitioner detained in Delhi Jail till disposal.
Defence of India Act LI of 1962 enacted, repealing Ordinance IV; s.48 deems actions under Ordinance as under Act from October 26, 1962.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Habeas Corpus petition under Art.32 is maintainable given President's Order under Art.359 suspending enforcement of Arts.21 and 22 during Emergency.
Whether the suspension order applies after repeal of Ordinance by Act LI of 1962, and effect of s.48 of the Act and s.8 of General Clauses Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Art.359 does not suspend Art.32 right; suspension depends on valid Ordinance which is invalid for lack of competence and spent force after repeal by Act LI.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.32, Art.359, Defence of India Ordinance IV 1962

petitioner_arguments.text: President's Order conditioned on deprivation under Ordinance; post-repeal, no fresh order, so merits can be examined including vires of Act and Rules.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Defence of India Act LI 1962 s.48

respondent_arguments.text: Preliminary objection: Petition not maintainable as President's Order suspends right to move court for Arts.21/22 enforcement during Emergency.
Words in President's Order descriptive, not condition precedent; s.48 of Act LI and s.8 General Clauses Act deem detention continued under Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Defence of India Act LI 1962 s.48, General Clauses Act s.8

court_reasoning.text: Art.32(4) allows suspension as per Constitution; Art.359 suspends right to move court for Arts.21/22 enforcement, not court's power; petitioner lacks locus standi during Emergency.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petitioner's right to move court suspended, though court's power intact.

court_reasoning.text: Cannot question vires without locus standi; President's Order applies post-repeal via s.48 Act LI deeming actions under Act, and s.8 General Clauses Act construing references to Ordinance as to re-enacted provisions; Order is 'instrument'.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legal fiction continues detention and suspension effect; no need for fresh order.

holdings.text: Preliminary objection upheld; petition not maintainable as right to enforce Arts.21/22 suspended under Art.359 during Emergency.
Detention order and suspension continue under Defence of India Act LI via s.48 and General Clauses Act s.8; President's Order governs.

precedents_cited.case_name: Stroud's Judicial Dictionary (3rd Ed., Vol.2, p.1472)
precedents_cited.relevance: Definition of 'instrument' includes formal legal writings like President's Order.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Emergency proclamation, suspension of rights to move court for Arts.21/22 enforcement, Art.32 not suspended except as provided.

statutes_cited.name: Defence of India Ordinance IV of 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowered rules for defence; basis for detention and suspension order.

statutes_cited.name: Defence of India Act LI of 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Repeals Ordinance but deems prior actions/rules as under Act from Oct 26, 1962.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act X of 1897
statutes_cited.relevance: References to repealed provisions construed as to re-enacted ones; applies to President's Order as 'instrument'.

outcome.summary: Court upheld respondent's preliminary objection, held petition not maintainable due to suspension of right to move court under Art.359 during Emergency; did not hear merits; detention continues validly.

key_quotes.text: "The right guaranteed by this article shall not be suspended except as otherwise provided for by the Constitution." (Art.32 cl.4)
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms Art.32 right suspendable per Constitution, including via Art.359.

key_quotes.text: Prima facie, therefore, the petitioners right to move this Court for a writ of Habeas Corpus... will remain suspended during the period of the Emergency.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning for dismissing petition on locus standi.

key_quotes.text: the petitioners right to move this Court, but not this Courts power under Art.32, has been suspended
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes right to approach from court's power.
